Author: Roshan Uikey
Comments: It is not a controversial issue, it is a reflection of the justice of the court.  The holy temple which was destroyed by the Mughal invaders about 500 years ago has been saved after many sacrifices and struggles.  Archaeological evidence of this has even been shown.  It was not just a matter of national pride or religious ambition, but added a unique dimension to the achievement of civilizational excellence and a blow to Mughal imperialism.  Hope the Sri Krishna temple and Kashi Vishwanath temple will be saved soon.  Jai Sriram  May God's grace be upon all.

Author: @agninagaseshu3216
Comments: The upcoming opening of the Ram Temple in Ayodhya  India has created a sense of global anticipation. The event scheduled for January 22nd, is not just being awaited by citizens of India, but by devotees and followers from around the world. The Vishwa Hindu Parishad  organized a car rally in New Jersey, United States as an early commemoration of the Pran Pratistha ceremony, with participation from the Hindu community across the region. The fervor extends to Nepal and Sri Lanka as well, with both countries contributing sacred gifts for the temple's construction. The Ram Lalla Idol, a symbol central to the temple's significance, is now stationed in the garbhagraha. The preparations for the temple's opening are shining a light on the unifying strength of shared devotion, transcending geographical boundaries. With excitement building across the globe, the Ram temple's opening is set to be a landmark moment not only for Ayodhya and India, but for the devotees worldwide.

Comments: Prime Minister Narendra Modi showcases a commitment to tradition and spirituality ahead of a significant Ayodhya event. Sleeping on a blanket on the floor and denying himself luxury, the PM only consumes Coconut water and participates daily in Gau Puja, a ritual feeding of cows. The Prime Minister also practices special mantras during the Brahma Muhurat for one hour and eleven minnutes. Embracing this fusion of spirituality and tradition,  the Prime Minister becomes an integral part of the divine choreography leading to the revered occasion in January at Ayodhya.

Author: @kavialaganarjunan7157
Comments:
It is so embarassing to see national newspapers talking about this princess Heo-Hwang-Okto be from Ayodhya in order to fit their funny agenda. The UP government and the central government have been reinterpreting history to suit their needs. 

"Heo was the princess of Ayuta Kingdom which was located in the southern part of India. Some people wrongly connect Ayuta Kingdom with Ayodhya. But the ancient name of Ayodhya was ‚ÄòSaketa‚Äô during that time and Samguk Yusa was written long back in the 13th century. Therefore it does not refer to Ayodhya. Ayuta Kingdom here refers to ‚ÄúAy Kingdom‚Äù that belonged to the Pandyan dynasty of ancient Tamilakam. This can be substantiated with the fact that princess Heo carried with her the symbol of Twin fish in trident. Pandyan Kingdom depicts two fishes on their flags, coins, and emblem. The fish symbol is considered to be one of the most meaningful symbols in the lives of the people living in Pandyan Kingdom. Princess Heo was also known by the name Sembavalam in Tamil which means red coral. Interestingly, the Korean name Heo Hwang-Ok also shares the same meaning. "

And for all those people who would be bashing me for these comments, you could go and check the similarities in the Tamil Culture and the Korean Culture. The words used, the traditions and there are several videos and documents on the internet that would prove this similarity. If any of you have a Korean friend you could ask them too. It is embarrassing how neither the Tamil Nadu State government nor the Central government is aware of this reinterpretation of history.

Author: @malinisarovar
Comments: Banking on a temple to boost India's soft power, even the need of discussing it in social media is not very promising for India's future. Religion has to be a personal choice. We don't want religion to be a factor to assert our power anywhere. Rather individuals should assert their power on their individual capabilities , talents and efforts. The same goes for the country. Sriram is always here, with or without the temple. If we can only feel his presence by a temple being built in Ayodhya, then all of us need to go back and study Ramayanam again and this time learn it the right way. Building this temple after all the tragic events that occured in past several hundred years, is historic and is a reason to rejoice for all those who has been waiting for this. Please leave it at that and don't connect it to the country's power.

The Ram Mandir is the focal rallying point for all Hindus as it stands now. But the custodians of the Hindu religion, the Sankaracharyas have unequivocally distanced themselves from the Ram Mandir. Nobody seems to have consulted them. Even if someone had consulted them, the Sankaracharyas would have not permitted the Ram Mandir to be built. People in the political establishment must have known it and hence the Sankaracharyas were bypassed. 

This is the sad part of the Ram Mandir. The temple for Lord Rama should be above all politics and selfish motives. Author: @ProudIndian55555
Comments:
Title: Hindu Population Growth: An Urgent Appeal for Survival and Preservation of Sanatan Dharma

Dear Hindus,

As we approach the year 2024, it is important for us to reflect on the current state of our country and the future that we want for ourselves and our children. One of the most pressing issues facing our community today is the rapidly increasing population of Muslims in India. While we must acknowledge the financial burden that comes with having a larger family, it is essential that we take action to ensure the survival and prosperity of our Hindu community.

As Hindus, it is our responsibility to preserve and protect our religion, Sanatan Dharma, from any potential threats. One way to do this is by ensuring a steady growth in our population. The truth is, the Muslim population is increasing at a faster rate than ours, and their high fertility rates may lead to domination and division in the future. As Hindus, we need to increase our fertility rates and have larger families to counter this growth, maintain our majority, and prevent our religion from being overtaken.


To achieve this, it is essential to have more marriages and kids before the age of 25. Although having multiple children can be financially challenging for a Hindu family, it is a small price to pay for the survival of our religion. We must also acknowledge that the Muslim population has increased from 9% to 20% in recent years, and if we continue to have only one child, they will outnumber us.


The history of our nation is marred by the partition and the slaughter of Hindus, which was a direct result of the Muslim population increasing at an alarming rate. Despite this, we have managed to maintain a large Hindu population for centuries, which allowed us to resist the attempts of the Muslim conquerors to convert us.

History has proven that whenever Muslim populations rise, they dominate and target minorities. We must learn from the past and prevent similar scenarios from occurring in the future. Sanatan Dharma has survived for centuries, and we must ensure that it continues to thrive by increasing our population. We must also work towards establishing a Hindu Rashtra to protect ourselves and our religion from any anti-Hindu elements.

Unfortunately, the demographics of our country are changing, and the Hindu population is declining at an alarming rate due to our low fertility rate. On the other hand, the Muslim population continues to increase at a much faster rate, which puts us at risk of becoming a minority in our own country.

It is important to note that history has repeatedly shown us that whenever the Muslim population percentage increases, they dominate and kill the minorities or divide the existing land. We cannot afford to let this happen again in India. The only way to save Sanatan Dharma and ensure the survival of our community is to have a higher fertility rate than the Muslims.

We must also remember that the goal of the Muslims is to establish Ghazwa-E-Hind, which means the conquest of India. We cannot let this become a reality. We want Akhand Bharat, but we want it to be our land and not be overrun by Muslims from neighboring countries.

Furthermore, it is crucial that we support political parties that have the best interest of the Hindu community at heart, and not be misled by anti-Hindu parties like Khangress.

I urge all Hindus to have at least three children and to get married and have children before the age of 25. We must take action to save our religion, Sanatan Dharma, and ourselves by multiplying ourselves as soon as possible.

In conclusion, it is crucial for all Hindus to come together and take action to increase our population by having more children and early marriages by 25. We must not be misled by those who seek to undermine our religion and instead focus on preserving Sanatan Dharma for generations to come. Let's multiply ourselves and save our religion, our culture, and our identity. Jai Hind! Jai Shree Ram!

Author: @kallachi729
Comments:
Smell the coffee.

Back in the late 1980s, I was posted in a government institution. In those days serial Ramayana was screened for an hour every Sunday morning. During times of heavy workload, because of the added work schedules, the institution worked on Sundays of some weeks. On those Sundays, I recall, the staff wanted an hour‚Äôs break between 09.30 ‚Äì 11.00 AM to watch the serial Ramayana. I believe the whole nation came to a standstill during the screening. BJP etc. was not even on the horizon during that period.

All said and done, the ‚ÄúRam Mandir‚Äù in Ayodhya will be a boost to the hospitality, travel and tourism industries while boosting the State and local economies.

Tailpiece: The stock value of L&T who constructed the Ram Temple, has almost doubled in the last one year.

Author: @venkataramansubramanian9288
Comments: The upcoming opening of the Ram Temple in Ayodhya  India has created a sense of global anticipation. The event scheduled for January 22nd, is not just being awaited by citizens of India, but by devotees and followers from around the world. The Vishwa Hindu Parishad  organized a car rally in New Jersey, United States as an early commemoration of the Pran Pratistha ceremony, with participation from the Hindu community across the region. The fervor extends to Nepal and Sri Lanka as well, with both countries contributing sacred gifts for the temple's construction. The Ram Lalla Idol, a symbol central to the temple's significance, is now stationed in the garbhagraha. The preparations for the temple's opening are shining a light on the unifying strength of shared devotion, transcending geographical boundaries. With excitement building across the globe, the Ram temple's opening is set to be a landmark moment not only for Ayodhya and India, but for the devotees worldwide.

Author: @FunnyIntelligentInnocentKids
Comments:
AHMEDABAD:¬†Gujarat still has a long way to go on the nutrition front as 38.09 per cent of the population in the state is undernourished, according to the National Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) report, released by Niti Aayog in July this year. Nearly half of the rural Gujarat population is deprived of nutrition (44.45 per cent), while the figure for urban areas is 28.97 per cent.

According to the Niti Aayog report, backward states such as Chhattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan and Uttar Pradesh have fared comparatively better than Gujarat on the nutrition front. Gujarat ranked fourth in terms of stunted children, according to data from NFHS 5 (National Family Health Survey). Thirty-nine per cent of children in the state are underweight for their age.

Furthermore, Gujarat ranked second in terms of wasted and underweight children, at 25.1 per cent and 39.7 per cent, respectively.¬† This reflects the state‚Äôs poor performance in terms of health metrics.

Analysing the MPI numbers, Atman Shah, Professor of Economics at St Xavier‚Äôs College, Ahmedabad, said, ‚ÄúNutrition is a serious cause for concern. In 2016, around 33.6 per cent of West Bengal families and 41.37 per cent of Gujarat households had at least one malnourished member. By 2021, this figure has dropped to 27.3 per cent in West Bengal and 38.9 per cent in Gujarat.‚Äù

Data clearly shows that three out of every 100 individuals in Gujarat were suffering from malnutrition during this time period, whilst West Bengal fared better with less than six out of every 100 people suffering from the condition, Shah added. Gujarat‚Äôs performance in housing also leaves room for improvement when compared to other states

Author: @yashasvi_karsh
Comments:
" Seems a disciple of a peaceful relegion. "
it was the matter of almost 500 years since demolition.
 ~half time since Arbi SHIT was found.
The claim that there is no evidence of Ram or Ram Mandir at the location in Ayodhya is disputable. Historical and archaeological research has suggested the presence of ancient structures at the site, supporting the belief in the existence of a Ram Temple. Additionally, the cultural and religious sentiments associated with Lord Ram hold significance for a large section of the population, making the construction of a Ram Temple a matter of faith and identity.

While acknowledging the historical presence of Buddhist artifacts, it's crucial to recognize the coexistence of diverse religious and cultural influences throughout history. Building a Ram Temple doesn't negate the importance of Buddhist heritage but rather reflects the rich tapestry of our cultural history.



Labeling the construction as an atrocity against specific social groups oversimplifies the complex dynamics involved. It's essential to foster inclusivity and dialogue, respecting the sentiments of all communities. The notion that Ayodhya's name contradicts Rama's warrior status is based on linguistic interpretation rather than historical evidence, highlighting the importance of relying on comprehensive research and scholarly discourse in such matters.

Author: @nirveshdagar
Comments:
Certainly! Here is a longer piece on Lord Shri Ram:

Lord Shri Ram, the revered seventh incarnation of Lord Vishnu in Hinduism, stands as a symbol of virtue, righteousness, and divine grace. The epic Ramayana, a sacred scripture in Hinduism, narrates the extraordinary life and deeds of Lord Ram, guiding millions of devotees on the path of dharma and spiritual awakening.

Born in Ayodhya to King Dasharatha and Queen Kaushalya, Lord Ram's divine aura was evident from his early days. His childhood exploits, including the breaking of Lord Shiva's bow to win the hand of Sita in marriage, foreshadowed the greatness that would define his life. As he embarked on his journey, the epic tale unfolded, revealing Lord Ram's unwavering commitment to truth and righteousness.

The essence of Lord Ram's character lies in his adherence to dharma, the righteous and moral order governing the universe. His exile to the forest, a consequence of fulfilling his father's promise to his stepmother Kaikeyi, exemplifies his commitment to duty above personal desires. Accompanied by his devoted wife Sita and loyal brother Lakshman, Lord Ram embraced the challenges of the wilderness with grace and fortitude.

The pinnacle of Lord Ram's trials came with the abduction of Sita by the demon king Ravana. The epic battle that ensued, culminating in the defeat of Ravana and the rescue of Sita, symbolizes the triumph of good over evil. Lord Ram's unwavering commitment to justice and righteousness became a beacon of hope for humanity, inspiring generations to confront adversity with courage and conviction.

The Ram Rajya, Lord Ram's reign as the ideal king in Ayodhya, is a legendary chapter in Hindu philosophy. During this period, Ayodhya prospered under his just and compassionate rule, establishing an era of harmony, prosperity, and ethical governance. The term "Ram Rajya" has transcended its mythological roots to signify an idyllic state of existence marked by justice, equality, and righteous leadership.

Lord Shri Ram's teachings, encapsulated in the conversations with sages like Vishwamitra and his encounters with various characters like Hanuman, underscore the principles of dharma and the path to spiritual enlightenment. The Hanuman Chalisa, a devotional hymn dedicated to Lord Hanuman, encapsulates the essence of devotion, loyalty, and the divine connection between the worshipper and the worshipped.

Devotees across the globe celebrate Lord Shri Ram through various festivals, with Ram Navami being one of the most significant. On this auspicious day, followers fast, read the Ramayana, and participate in prayers to commemorate the divine birth of Lord Ram. The recitation of the Sundara Kanda, a book in the Ramayana narrating Hanuman's journey to Lanka, is considered particularly auspicious during this time.

The cultural impact of Lord Shri Ram extends beyond religious boundaries. His life has inspired countless literary works, dance dramas, and artistic expressions, transcending geographical and linguistic barriers. The Ram Leela, a traditional form of storytelling through theatrical performances, has been a cornerstone of cultural celebrations, fostering a sense of community and shared devotion.

In the heart of Ayodhya, the Ram Janmabhoomi, believed to be the birthplace of Lord Ram, holds immense significance for devotees. The construction of the Ram Mandir at this sacred site has been a focal point of devotion, marking a historic moment for millions who have longed to see a grand temple dedicated to their beloved Lord.

Beyond the epic narrative, Lord Shri Ram's life serves as a spiritual guide, offering profound insights into the nature of existence and the pursuit of a purposeful life. His teachings emphasize the importance of duty, righteousness, and devotion, serving as a compass for navigating the complexities of the material and spiritual realms.

The philosophical underpinnings of Lord Shri Ram's life resonate in the concept of "Ram Rajya" as an ideal socio-political order. It envisions a society where justice prevails, leaders uphold righteous governance, and citizens live harmoniously, adhering to ethical principles. This utopian vision continues to inspire leaders, thinkers, and policymakers to strive for a just and compassionate world.

Devotees often find solace and strength in chanting the name of Lord Ram, as it is believed to have transformative powers. The repetition of the divine mantra, "Ram Naam," is a practice embedded in the spiritual journey, fostering a deep connection with the divine and providing solace during challenging times.

In conclusion, the saga of Lord Shri Ram extends far beyond the realms of mythology. It is a timeless narrative that transcends generations, cultures, and borders, serving as a beacon of divine guidance and moral principles. Lord Ram's life, teachings, and legacy continue to shape the spiritual consciousness of millions, offering a profound understanding of life's purpose and the eternal quest for righteousness and truth.

Comments: Thank you to Pooja Shali for a meaningful presentation on the temple reconstruction in Ayodhya for Shri Ram! When one questions why Shri Ram is revered in so many countries, the reasons are perhaps more than historical. During the course of his life and struggles, to his ultimate victory, Shri Ram espoused the values of personal integrity, a sense of duty, patience, humility, fortitude and valour. To Hindus and to global believers, Shri Ram was perhaps the earliest known example of a person who despite his birth into royalty and grandeur, faced the travails of his life with the strength of character, so much so that he has become the epitome of ethical, moral and spiritual values, that resonate across cultural and geographical boundaries.

Kindly do not use the word 'idol' for Ram in the temple. Hindus are not idol worshippers. We worship the 'vigraha'..'arch vigrah'....'deity' or even the 'murti' after pran pratisthan.( a spiritual process that bestows grace on the material form, making it spiritual in essence)..hence murti shd t be confused with ,'statue'...

Please bear this in mind and stop using the word 'idol'.
